Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2012 10:29AM markat wrote: Darnette, everyone is so different with recovery. I had a BMX with TE's. I had 2 drainage tubes placed under my TE's. The tubes were the worst part for me with my recovery. Most women get the tubes pulled in 1-2 weeks. Some have to keep them in longer, it just depends on your surgeon and what their protocol is for the amount the drainage needs to be under. The first 6 weeks was the hardest, but I feel so much better now. I also had chemo before so I think that adds to the recovery time. Our bodies need a little extra healing time. I can't wait to have my TE exchange, but I'm also nervous because I'm used to them now.

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2012 07:05PM markat wrote: Yep Darnette, the TEs look like breasts under clothes. You start out at surgery with them either empty or filled to a certain CC level. Then every week or two weeks you go to your plastic surgeon and get them filled with saline. When you reach your desired size and the surgeon decides that you have waited long enough, you get the permanent implants. TEs were a good option for me, but the DIEP sounds like a really good option too.
Posts.Title: Any August 2012 girls? shabby6485 Beckers

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2012 07:10AM markat wrote: The tissue expander (TE) experience is different for everyone. In my own experience, it took 6 weeks for me to feel comfortable with them. They actually became more comfortable with fills. The filling of the TE with saline did not hurt, because you will probably be numb in that area. After the fills, you might experience tightness as your pec muscles expand. Of course this is my own experience and others may go through more or less pain. I am thrilled that my PS is doing the exchange after 3 months instead of 4-6. I think you may read about a lot of problems on these boards because people come here looking for answers.
